intro: Nerisyrenia castillonii, commonly known as the Castillon's lily, is a rare and striking flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of southern Spain. It belongs to the Liliaceae family and is characterized by its tall, slender stems and large, showy white or pinkish flowers. The plant typically blooms in late spring to early summer, producing clusters of fragrant, bell-shaped flowers that attract pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, Nerisyrenia castillonii is considered a vulnerable species, highlighting the importance of conservation efforts to protect its natural environment.
